And certainly the sin of idolatry is the first thing that God forbids in the Ten Commandments, as witness Exodus 20: “Thou shalt have no other gods before me; thou shalt not make unto thee any graven image.” Thus an avaricious man, who loveth his treasure more than God, is an idolater by reason of this cursed sin of avarice.

Of covetousness come these hard exactions whereby men are assessed and made to pay taxes, rents, and payments in lieu of service, more than duty requires or reason demands. Also they take from their serfs amercements that might more reasonably be called extortions than amercements. As to which amercements and fines of serfs, some lords’ stewards say that it is just, forasmuch as a churl hath no temporal thing that is not his lord’s, so they say. But certainly these lordships do wrong that bereave their bond-folk of things that they never gave them (Augustinus, De Civitate Dei, Book IX). Sooth is that the condition of thraldom and the first cause of thraldom is sin (Genesis 9).

Thus may ye see that the guilt deserveth thraldom, but not nature. Wherefore these lords should not much glorify themselves in their lordships, since by natural condition they are not lords of thralls; but for that thraldom came first by the desert of sin. And furthermore, where the law saith that temporal goods of bondmen be the goods of their lord, ye, that is to say, it is to be understood as the goods of the emperor, to defend them in their right, but not to rob them nor to reave them. And therefore says Seneca: “Thy prudence should live benignly with thy thralls.” Those that thou clepest thy thralls are God’s people; for humble folk be Christ’s friends; they be at home with the Lord.

Think also that of such seed as churls spring, of such seed spring lords. As well may the churl be saved as the lord. The same death that taketh the churl taketh the lord. Wherefore I rede, do right so with thy churl as thou wouldest that thy lord did with thee, if thou were in his plight. Every sinful man is a churl to sin. I rede thee, certes, that thou, lord, work in such wise with thy churls that they rather love thee than dread. I wot well there is degree above degree, as reason is; and it is right that men do their devoir where it is due; but certes, extortions and despite of your underlings is damnable.

And furthermore understand well that these conquerors or tyrants make full oft thralls of them that were born of as royal blood as they that conquer them. This name of thraldom was never erst known until Noah said that his son Canaan should be thrall to his brethren for his sin. What say we then of them that pill and do extortions to holy church? Certainly the sword that men give first to a knight when he is newly dubbed signifieth that he should defend holy church, and not rob nor pillage it; and who so doth, is traitor to Christ. And, as Saint Augustine says, “they are the Devil’s wolves that strangle the sheep of Jesus Christ”; and do worse than wolves. For truly when the wolf hath filled his womb he ceaseth to strangle sheep. But certes the pillers and destroyers of God’s holy church do not so; for they never cease to pill. Now, as I have said, since sin was the first cause of thraldom, then was it thus that the time when all the world was in sin, the world was in thraldom and subjection. But certainly, since the time of grace came, God ordained that some folk should be more high in estate and in degree, and some folk more low, and that each should

---

> 57. Of the remedie of thise two sinnes, as seith the wyse man, that “he that dredeth God, he spareth nat to doon that which him oghte doon.” And he that loveth God, he wol doon diligence to plese God by his werkes, and abaundone himself, with al his might, wel for to doon. Thanne comth idelnesse, that is the gate of alle harmes. An idel man is lyk to a place that hath no walles; the develes may entre on every side and sheten at him at discovert, by temptacion on every side. This idelnesse is the thurrok of alle wicked and vileyns thoghtes, and of alle jangles, trifles, and of alle ordure. Certes the hevene is yeven to hem that wol labouren, and nat to idel folk. Eek David seith that “they ne been nat in the labour of men, ne they shul nat been whipped with men,” that is to seyn, in Purgatorie. Certes thanne semeth it, they shul be tormented with the devel in helle, but-if they doon penance.

> 58. Thanne comth the sinne that men clepen Tarditas, as whan a man is to latiede or taryinge er he wole turne to God; and certes, that is a greet folye. He is lyk to him that falleth in the diche, and wol nat arise. And this vice comth of a fals hope, that he thinketh that he shal live longe; but that hope faileth ful ofte.

> 59. Thanne comth Lachesse; that is he, that whan he biginneth any good werk, anon he shal forleten it and stinten; as doon they that han any wight to governe, and ne taken of him na-more kepe, anon as they finden any contrarie or any annoy. Thise been the newe shepherdes, that leten hir sheep witingly go renne to the wolf that is in the breres, or do no fors of hir owene governaunce. Of this comth poverte and destruccioun, bothe of spirituel and temporel thinges. Thanne comth a manere coldnesse, that freseth al the herte of man. Thanne comth undevocioun, thurgh which a man is so blent, as seith seint Bernard, and hath swiche langour in soule, that he may neither rede ne singe in holy chirche, ne here ne thinke of no devocioun, ne travaille with hise handes in no good werk, that it nis him unsavory and al apalled. Thanne wexeth he slow and slombry, and sone wol be wrooth, and sone is enclyned to hate and to envie. Thanne comth the sinne of worldly sorwe, swich as is cleped tristitia, that sleeth man, as seint Paul seith. For certes, swich sorwe werketh to the deeth of the soule and of the body also; for therof comth, that a man is anoyed of his owene lyf. Wherefore swich sorwe shorteth ful ofte the lyf of a man, er that his tyme be come by wey of kinde.

> 60. Agayns this horrible sinne of Accidie, and the branches of the same, ther is a vertu that is called Fortitudo or Strength; that is, an affeccion thurgh which a man despiseth anoyous thinges. This vertu is so mighty and so vigorous, that it dar withstande mightily and wysely kepen himself fro perils that been wikked, and wrastle agayn the assautes of the devel. For it enhaunceth and enforceth the soule, right as Accidie abateth it and maketh it feble. For this Fortitudo may endure by long suffraunce the travailles that been covenable.

> 61. This vertu hath manye speces; and the firste is cleped Magnanimitee, that is to seyn, greet corage. For certes, ther bihoveth greet corage agains Accidie, lest that it ne swolwe the soule by the sinne of sorwe, or destroye it by wanhope. This vertu maketh folk to undertake harde thinges and grevouse thinges, by hir owene wil, wysely and resonably. And for as muchel as the devel fighteth agayns a man more by queyntise and by sleighte than by strengthe, therfore men shal withstanden him by wit and by resoun and by discrecion. Thanne am ther the vertues of feith, and hope in God and in his seintes, to acheve and acomplice the gode werkes in the whiche he purposeth fermely to continue. Thanne comth seuretee or sikernesse; and that is, whan a man ne douteth no travail in tyme cominge of the gode werkes that a man hath bigonne. Thanne comth Magnificence, that is to seyn, whan a man dooth and perfoumeth grete werkes of goodnesse that he hath bigonne; and that is the ende why that men sholde do gode werkes; for in the acomplissinge of grete gode werkes lyeth the grete guerdoun. Thanne is ther Constaunce, that is, stablencsse of corage; and this sholde been in herte by stedefast feith, and in mouth, and in beringe, and in chere and in dede. Eke ther been mo speciale remedies agayns Accidie, in diverse werkes, and in consideracioun of the peynes of helle, and of the joyes of hevene, and in trust of the grace of the holy goost, that wol yeve him might to perfoume his gode entente.

> 62. After Accidie wol I speke of Avarice and of Coveitise, of which sinne seith seint Paule, that “the rote of alle harmes is Coveitise”: Ad Timotheum, sexto capitulo. For soothly, whan the herte of a man is confounded in it-self and troubled, and that the soule hath lost the confort of God, thanne seketh he an ydel solas of worldly thinges.

> 63. Avarice, after the descripcion of seint Augustin, is likerousnesse in herte to have erthely thinges. Som other folk seyn, that Avarice is, for to purchacen manye erthely thinges, and nothing yeve to hem that han nede. And understond, that Avarice ne stant nat only in lond ne catel, but somtyme in science and in glorie, and in every manere of outrageous thing is Avarice and Coveitise. And the difference bitwixe Avarice and Coveitise is this. Coveitise is for to coveite swiche thinges as thou hast nat; and Avarice is for to withholde and kepe swiche thinges as thou hast, with-oute rightful nede. Soothly, this Avarice is a sinne that is ful dampnable; for al holy writ curseth it, and speketh agayns that vice; for it dooth wrong to Jesu Crist. For it bireveth him the love that men to him owen, and turneth bakward agayns alle resoun; and maketh that the avaricious man hath more hope in his catel than in Jesu Crist, and dooth more observance in kepinge of his tresor than he dooth to service of Jesu Crist. And therfore seith seint Paule ad Ephesios, quinto, that “an avaricious man is in the thraldom of idolatrie.”

> 64. What difference is bitwixe an idolastre and an avaricious man, but that an idolastre, per aventure, ne hath but o mawmet or two, and the avaricious man hath manye? For certes, every florin in his cofre is his mawmet. And certes, the sinne of Mawmetrye is the firste thing that God deffended in the ten comaundments, as bereth witnesse Exodi, capitulo xx°: “Thou shalt have no false goddes bifore me, ne thou shalt make to thee no grave thing.” Thus is an avaricious man, that loveth his tresor bifore God, an idolastre, thurgh this cursed sinne of Avarice. Of Coveitise comen these harde lordshipes, thurgh whiche men been distreyned by tailages, custumes, and cariages, more than hir dutee or resoun is. And eke they taken of hir bonde-men amerciments, whiche mighten more resonably ben eleped extorcions than amerciments. Of whiche amerciments and raunsoninges of bonde- men, somme lordes’ stewardes seyn, that it is rightful; for-as-muche-as a churl hath no temporel thing that it ne is his lordes, as they seyn. But certes, these lordshipes doon wrong, that bireven hir bonde-folk thinges that they never yave hem: Augustinus, De Civitate Dei, libro nono. Sooth is, that the condicioun of thraldom and the firste cause of thraldom is for sinne; Genesis, ix.

> 65. Thus may ye seen that the gilt disserveth thraldom, but nat nature. Wherfore these lordes ne sholde nat muche glorifyen hem in hir lord- ships, sith that by naturel condicion they been nat lordes of thralles; but for that thraldom comth first by the desert of sinne. And forther-over, ther-as the lawe seith, that temporel godes of bonde-folk been the godes of hir lordshipes, ye, that is for to understonde, the godes of the emperour, to deffenden hem in hir right, but nat for to robben hem ne reven hem. And therfore seith Seneca: “Thy prudence sholde live benignely with thy thralles.” Thilke that thou clepest thy thralles been goddes peple; for humble folk been Cristes freendes; they been contubernial with the lord.

> 66. Think eek, that of swich seed as cherles springeth, of swich seed springen lordes. As wel may the cherl be saved as the lord. The same deeth that taketh the cherl, swich deeth taketh the lord. Wherfore I rede, do right so with thy cherl, as thou woldest that thy lord dide with thee, if thou were in his plyt. Every sinful man is a cherl to sinne. I rede thee, certes, that thou, lord, werke in swiche wyse with thy cherles, that they rather love thee than drede. I woot wel ther is degree above degree, as reson is; and skile it is, that men do hir devoir ther-as it is due; but certes, extorcions and despite of youre underlinges is dampnable.

> 67. And forther-over understond wel, that these conquerours or tiraunts maken ful ofte thralles of hem, that been born of as royal blood as been they that hem conqueren. This name of thraldom was never erst couth, til that Noe seyde, that his sone Canaan sholde be thral to his bretheren for his sinne. What seye we thanne of hem that pilen and doon extorcions to holy chirche? Certes, the swerd, that men yeven first to a knight whan he is newe dubbed, signifyeth that he sholde deffenden holy chirche, and nat robben it ne pilen it; and who so dooth, is traitour to Crist. And, as seith seint Augustin, “they been the develes wolves, that strangle the sheep of Jesu Crist”; and doon worse than wolves. For soothly, whan the wolf hath ful his wombe, he stinteth to strangle sheep. But soothly, the pilours and destroyours of goddes holy chirche ne do nat so; for they ne stint nevere to pile. Now, as I have seyd, sith so is that sinne was first cause of thraldom, thanne is it thus; that thilke tyme that al this world was in sinne, thanne was al this world in thraldom and subjeccioun. But certes, sith the tyme of grace cam, God ordeyned that som folk sholde be more heigh in estaat and in degree, and som folk more lowe, and that everich sholde

## (Text continues)

# THE PARSON’S TALE

## Simony and Spiritual Trade

There are permitted trades by which merchants may bring merchandise from one country to another. That other trade, which men barter with fraud and treachery and deceit, with lies and with false oaths, is accursed and damnable. Spiritual trade is properly *simony* — the earnest desire to buy spiritual things, that is to say, things that appertain to the sanctuary of God and to the cure of the soul. This desire, if a man is diligent in accomplishing it, even though his desire have no effect, yet it is a deadly sin; and if he be ordained he sins against his orders.

Simony is named for Simon Magus, who would have bought, with temporal wealth, the gift that God had given, by the Holy Ghost, to Saint Peter and to the other apostles. And therefore you should understand that both he that buys and he that sells spiritual things are called simonists; be it by means of chattels, or by entreaty, or by fleshly asking of his friends — fleshly friends or spiritual friends. Fleshly friends are of two kinds: kindred and other friends.

Truly, if they ask for one who is not worthy and able, it is simony if he take the benefice; but if he be worthy and able, it is not. The other kind is when a man or woman asks folk to advance him or her only for wicked fleshly affection that they may have for that person; and that is vile simony. But certainly, in that service for which men give spiritual things unto their servants, it must be understood that the service is honest; and also that it be done without bargaining, and that the person be able.

For, as Saint Damasus says:  
> “All the sins of the world, compared to this sin, are as naught.”

For it is the greatest sin that may be done after that of Lucifer and Antichrist. For by this sin God loses the Church and the soul that He bought with His precious blood, because of those who give churches to those who are not worthy. For they put in thieves, who steal souls from Jesus Christ and destroy His patrimony. By reason of such unworthy priests and curates, ignorant men have the less reverence for the sacraments of Holy Church; and such givers of churches put out the children of Christ and put in the Devil’s own sons. They sell the souls that they watch over as lambs to the wolf that rends them. And therefore they shall never have any part in the pasture of lambs, that is, the bliss of Heaven.

Now comes hazardry with its appurtenances, such as tables and raffles, whence come deceit, false oaths, chidings, and hatred of one’s neighbours, waste of goods, misspending of time, and sometimes manslaughter. Certainly, hazarders cannot be without great sin while they haunt that craft. Of avarice come also lies, theft, false witnessing, and false oaths. And you shall understand that these are great sins, and expressly against the commandments of God, as I have said.

False witness is in word and also in deed. In word, as by bereaving thy neighbour’s good name by thy false witnessing, or bereaving him of his chattels or his heritage by thy false witnessing; when thou, for ire or for reward, or for envy, bearest false witness, or accusest him or excusest him by thy false witness, or else excusest thyself falsely. Beware, you jurymen and notaries! Certainly, by false witness was Susanna in full great sorrow and pain, and many another more.

The sin of theft is also expressly against God’s commandment, and that in two manners, corporal and spiritual. Corporal, as taking thy neighbour’s chattels against his will, be it by force or by sleight, be it by short measure or by false measure; by stealing also of false indictments upon him, and in borrowing of thy neighbour’s chattels in intent never to pay them again, and similar things. Spiritual theft is sacrilege, that is to say, hurting of holy things, or of things sacred to Christ, in two manners: by reason of the holy place, as churches or churchyards, for which every vile sin that men do in such places may be called sacrilege, or every violence in such places; and also they that withdraw falsely the rights that belong to Holy Church.

And plainly and generally, sacrilege is to take away a holy thing from a holy place, or an unholy thing out of a holy place, or a holy thing out of an unholy place.

---

## The Relief against the Sin of Avarice

68. Now shall you understand that the relief of avarice is *misericorde* and pity, largely taken. And men might ask why mercy and pity relieve avarice. Certainly, the avaricious man shows no pity nor any mercy to the needy man; for he delights in keeping his treasure and not in the rescuing or relieving of his fellow Christian. And therefore will I speak first of mercy.

Mercy, as the philosopher says, is a virtue whereby the feelings of a man are moved by the trouble of him that is in distress. Upon which mercy follows pity and performs charitable works of mercy. And certainly, these things impel a man to the mercy of Jesus Christ—that He gave Himself for our sins, and suffered death for the sake of mercy, and forgave us our original sins; and thereby released us from the pains of Hell and lessened the pains of Purgatory by means of penitence, and gives us grace to do good, and, at the last, gives us the bliss of Heaven.

The kinds of mercy are: to lend, and to give, and to forgive, and to set free, and to have pity in heart and compassion on the tribulations of one’s fellow Christian, and also to chastise, as need may be. Another kind of remedy for avarice is reasonable largess; and truly, here it behooves one to give consideration to the grace of Jesus Christ, and to one’s temporal wealth, and also to the perdurable wealth that Christ gave to us; and to remember the death that he shall receive—he knows not when, where, or how—and also that he must forgo all that he has, save only that which he has invested in good works.

But forasmuch as some folk are immoderate, men ought to avoid foolish largess, which men call waste. Certainly, he that is prodigal gives not his wealth, but loses his wealth. Truly, that which he gives out of vainglory, as to minstrels and to followers, in order to have his renown carried about the world, he does sin thereby rather than give alms. Certainly, he shamefully loses his wealth who seeks in the gift thereof nothing but sin. He is like a horse that chooses rather to drink muddy or turbid water than the clear water of a well. And forasmuch as they give where they should not give, to them belongs that cursing which Christ will give at the day of doom to those that shall be damned.

---

## Here followeth Gluttony

After avarice comes gluttony, which also is entirely against the commandment of God. Gluttony is immoderate appetite to eat or to drink, or else to yield to the immoderate desire to eat or to drink. This sin corrupted all this world, as is well shown by the sin of Adam and Eve. Read also what Saint Paul says of gluttony:

> “For many walk, of whom I have told you often, and now tell you even weeping, that they are the enemies of the cross of Christ: whose end is destruction, whose God is their belly, and whose glory is in their shame, who mind earthly things.”

He that is addicted to this sin of gluttony may withstand no other sin. He must be in the service of all vices, for it is in the Devil’s hoard that he hides himself and rests.

This sin has many species. The first is drunkenness, which is the horrible sepulture of man’s reason; and therefore, when a man is drunk he has lost his reason; and this is deadly sin. But truly, when a man is not wont to strong drink, and perhaps knows not the strength of the drink, or is feeble in his head, or has travailed, through which he drinketh the more, though he be suddenly taken with drink, it is not a deadly sin, but venial.

The second species of gluttony is when the spirit of a man groweth all disturbed; for drunkenness bereaveth him the discretion of his wit. The third species of gluttony is when a man devoureth his meat and hath no rightful manner of eating. The fourth is when, through the great abundance of his meat, the humours in his body are distempered. The fifth is forgetfulness by too much drinking; for which sometimes a man forgets ere the morrow what he did at even or on the night before.

In another manner are the species of gluttony distinguished, after Saint Gregory. The first is to eat before the time to eat. The second is when a man gets himself delicate meat or drink. The third is when men take too much beyond measure. The fourth is curiosity, with great intent to make and to apparell his meat. The fifth is to eat too greedily. These be the five fingers of the Devil’s hand, by which he draweth folk to sin.

---

## The Remedy against Gluttony

72. Against gluttony the remedy is abstinence, as Galen says; but that I hold not meritorious if he do it only for the health of his body. Saint Augustine wills that abstinence be done for virtue and with patience. Abstinence, he says, is little worth unless a man have good will thereto, and unless it be enforced by patience and by charity, and that men do it for God’s sake, and in hope to have the bliss of Heaven.

73. The fellows of abstinence are temperance, which keepeth the mean in all things; also shame, which escheweth all dishonesty; sufficiency, which seeketh no rich meats nor drinks, nor maketh any force of too outrageous appareling of meat. Measure also, which restraineth by reason the enslaved appetite of eating; sobriety also, which restraineth the outrage of drinking; sparingness also, which restraineth the delicate ease to sit long at his meat and softly; wherefore some folk stand of their own will, to eat with less leisure.

---

## Here followeth Lechery

74. After gluttony, then cometh lechery; for these two sins are so near cousins that oftentimes they will not depart. God wot, this sin is full displeasing to God; for He said Himself, “Do no lechery.” And therefore He put great penalties against this sin in the old law. If a bondwoman were taken in this sin, she should be beaten to death with staves. And if she were a gentlewoman she should be slain with stones. And if she were a bishop’s daughter she should be burned, by God’s commandment. Furthermore, for the sin of lechery God drowned all the world by the deluge. And after that He burned five cities with thunderbolts and sank them into Hell.

Now let us speak then of that stinking sin of lechery that men call adultery of wedded folk, that is to say, if one of them be wedded, or else both. Saint John saith that adulterers shall be in the lake which burneth with fire and brimstone — in the fire for the lechery, in brimstone for the stink of their filthiness. Certainly, the breaking of this sacrament is a horrible thing; it was ordained by God Himself in Paradise, and confirmed by Jesus Christ, as witness Saint Matthew in the Gospel: “For this cause shall a man leave father and mother, and shall cleave to his wife; and they twain shall be one flesh.” This sacrament betokeneth the knitting together of Christ and of Holy Church.

And not only did God forbid adultery in deed, but also He commanded that “thou shalt not covet thy neighbour’s wife.” This behest, says Saint Augustine, containeth the forbidding of all desire to do lechery. Behold what Saint Matthew says in the Gospel: “Whosoever looketh on a woman to lust after her hath committed adultery with her already in his heart.” Here you may see that not only the doing of this sin is forbidden, but also the desire to do that sin. This accursed sin grievously troubles those whom it haunts.

And first, it does harm to the soul; for it constraineth it to sin and to the pain of everlasting death. Unto the body it is a tribulation also, for it draineth it, and wasteth and ruineth it, and maketh of its blood a sacrifice to the Fiend of Hell; also it wasteth wealth and substance. And certainly, if it be a foul thing for a man to waste his wealth on women, it is yet fouler when, for such filthiness, women spend on men their wealth and their substance. This sin, as saith the prophet, robbeth man and woman of good name and of all honour; and it giveth great pleasure to the Devil, for thereby won he the greater part of the world. And just as a merchant delighteth most in that trading whereof he reapeth the greater gain, just so the Fiend delighteth in this filth.

This is the Devil’s other hand, with five fingers to catch the people into his slavery. The first finger is the foolish interchange of glances between the foolish woman and the foolish man, which slayeth just as the basilisk slayeth folk by the venom of its sight; for the lust of the eyes followeth the lust of the heart. The second finger is vile touching in wicked manner; and thereupon Solomon saith that he who toucheth and handleth a woman fares like the man that handleth the scorpion which stingeth and suddenly killeth by its poisoning; even as, if any man touche warm pitch, it defileth his fingers. The third is vile words, which are like fire, which immediately burn the heart. The fourth finger is kissing; and truly he were a great fool who would kiss the mouth of a burning oven. The fifth finger is lustful accord and intimate dalliance, by which they consent, and the deed is accomplished.

---

## Middle English (Original Text, cleaned)

are permitted to be merchants to bring from one country to the other their merchandise. That other trade, which men barter with fraud and treachery and deceit, with lies and with false oaths, is accursed and damnable. Spiritual trade is properly *Symonye*, that is, earnest desire to buy spiritual things, that is, things that appertain to the sanctuary of God and to the cure of the soul. This desire, if so be that a man do his diligence to perform it, albeit that his desire ne take no effect, yet is it to him a deadly sin; and if he be ordained, he is irregular.

Certes, Symonye is cleped of Symon Magus, that wolde han bought, for temporel catel, the gift that God hadde given, by the Holy Ghost, to Saint Peter and to the apostles. And therefore understond, that both he that selleth and he that buyeth things espiritual, been cleped Simonials; be it by catel, be it by procuringe, or by fleshly prayer of his friends, fleshly friends or espiritual friends. Fleshly, in two maneres; as by kinrede or other friends. Soothly, if they pray for him that is not worthy and able, it is Symonye if he take the benefice; and if he be worthy and able, ther is none.

That other manere is, whan a man or woman preyen folk to advance hem only for wicked fleshly affection that they have unto the person; and that is foul Symonye. But certes, in service for which men yeven things espiritual unto hir servants, it moot be understood that the service moot be honest, and *eles* not; and eke that it be without bargaining, and that the persone be able. For, as seith Saint Damasus, “Alle the sinnes of the world, compared to this sinne, ben as nought”; for it is the greatest sinne that may be, after the sinne of Lucifer and Antichrist. For, by this sinne God forleeth the Church, and the soul that He bought with His precious blood, by them that yeven churches to them that been not digne. For they putten in thieves, that stealen the souls of Jesu Christ and destroyen His patrimony. By swiche undigne preestes and curates han lewed men the less reverence of the sacraments of holy Church; and swiche yevers of churches putten out the children of Christ, and putten into the church the Devil’s own son. They sell the souls that lambes should keep to the wolf that strangeth them. And therefore shul they never have part of the pasture of lambes, that is, the bliss of Heaven.

Now comth hasardrye with his appurtenances, as tables and raffles, of which cometh deceit, false oaths, chidings, and all ravines, blaspheming and reneying of God, and hate of his neighbours, wast of goods, misspending of time, and sometime manslaughter. Certes, hasardours ne may not be without great sinne while they haunt that craft. Of avarice comen eke lies, theft, false witness, and false oaths. And ye shul understand that these been great sins, and express against the commandments of God, as I have said.

False witness is in word and eke in deed. In word, as for to bereave thy neighbour’s good name by thy false witnessing, or bereave him his chattels or his heritage by thy false witnessing; when thou, for ire or for mede, or for envy, bearest false witness, or accusest him or excusest him by thy false witness, or else excusest thyself falsely. Beware ye, questmongers and notaries! Certes, for false witnessing was Susanna in full great sorrow and pain, and many another more. The sinne of theft is eke express against God’s hest, and that in two maneres, corporel and espiritual. Corporel, as for to take thy neighbour’s catel again his will, be it by force or by sleight, be it by short measure or by false measure. By stealing eke of false indictments upon him, and in borrowing of thy neighbour’s catel in intent never to pay it again, and semblable things.

Espiritual theft is Sacrilege, that is to say, hurting of holy things, or of things sacred to Christ, in two maneres; by reason of the holy place, as churches or church-yards, for which every vile sin that men do in such places may be called sacrilege, or every violence in such places. Also they that withdraw falsely the rights that longen to holy Church. And plainly and generally, sacrilege is to reave holy thing from holy place, or unholy thing out of holy place, or holy thing out of unholy place.
