### The Relief against the Sin of Avarice (Middle English)

68. Now shul ye understande, that the relieving of Avarice is *misericorde* and pitee largely taken. And men mighten axe, why that misericorde and pitee is relievinge of Avarice? Certes, the avaricious man sheweth no pitee ne misericorde to the needful man; for he deliteth him in the keeping of his tresor, and not in the rescuing ne relieving of his evene-cristene. And therfor speke I first of misericorde.

Thanne is misericorde, as seith the philosophe, a virtue by which the courage of man is stirred by the misse of him that is misused. Upon which misericorde followeth pitee in performing of charitable workes of misericorde. And certes, these thinges move a man to misericorde of Jesu Christ, that He yaf Himself for our gilt, and suffered death for misericorde, and forgaf us our original sinnes; and thereby released us fro the paines of Hell, and lessened the paines of Purgatory by penitence, and yeveth grace well to do, and at the last the bliss of Heaven. The species of misericorde been, as for to lene and for to yeve and to foryeve and release, and for to have pitee in heart, and compassion of the mischief of his evene-cristene, and eke to chastise there as need is. Another manere of remedie against Avarice is reasonable largesse; but soothly, here behoveth consideration of the grace of Jesu Christ, and of his temporal goods, and eke of the goods perdurable that Christ yaf to us; and to have remembrance of the death that he shall receive, he knoweth not when, where, nor how; and eke that he shall forgo all that he hath, save only that he hath expended in good workes.

69. But forasmuche as some folk be unmeasurable, men ought to eschew fool-largesse, that men clepen wast. Certes, he that is fool-large ne yeveth not his catel, but he loseth his catel. Soothly, that which he yeveth for vaine glory, as to minstrels and to folk, for to bear his renown in the world, he hath sinne there-of and none almesse. Certes, he loseth foule his good, that ne seeketh with the gift of his good nothing but sinne. He is like to a horse that seeketh rather to drinken drowy or troubled water than for to drink water of the clear well. And forasmuch as they yiven there as they should not yiven, to them appertaineth that malediction that Christ shall give at the day of doom to them that shall be damned.

---

## Here followeth Gluttony (Middle English)

70. After Avarice comth Glotonye, which is express eke again the commandment of God. Glotonye is unmeasured appetit to ete or to drinke, or else to doon y-nough to the unmeasured appetite and disorderly covetise to eten or to drinke. This sinne corrupted all this world, as is well shewed in the sinne of Adam and of Eve. Loke eke what seith Saint Paul of Glotonye. “Manye,” seith Saint Paul, “goon, of which I have ofte seyd to yow, and now I seie it weeping, that they been the enemys of the croys of Crist; of which the ende is deeth, and of which hir wombe is hir god, and hir glorie in confusion of hem that so saveren erthely thinges.” He that is use to this sinne of Glotonye ne may no sinne withstande. He moot been in servage of alle vices, for it is the Devil’s hoard where he hideth him and resteth.

This sinne hath many species. The first is drunkenesse, that is the horrible sepulture of mannes reason; and therefore, whan a man is drunken, he hath lost his reason; and this is deadly sinne. But soothly, whan a man is not wont to strong drinke, and peraventure knoweth not the strengths of the drinke, or hath feblesse in his head, or hath travailed, through which he drinketh the more, albeit he be sodeynly caught with drinke, it is no deadly sinne, but venial. The second species of Glotonye is that the spirit of a man waxeth all troubled; for drunkenesse bereveth him the discretion of his wit. The third species is whan a man devoureth his meat and hath no rightful manner of eating. The fourth is whan, through the great abundance of his meat, the humours in his body be distempered. The fifth is forgetfulness by too much drinking; for which sometimes a man forgeteth ere the morrow what he did at even or on the night before.

71. In other maner been distinct the species of Glotonye, after Saint Gregorie. The first is for to ete before time to ete. The second is whan a man get him to delicate mete or drinke. The third is whan men taken to muche over measure. The fourth is curiositie, with great intent to make and apparellen his mete. The fifth is for to eten too greedily. These been the five fingers of the Devyl’s hand, by which he draweth folk to sinne.

---

## The Remedy against Gluttony (Middle English)

72. Agayns Glotonye is the remedie Abstinence, as seith Galien; but that holde I not meritorie, if he do it only for the hele of his body. Saint Augustin woll that Abstinence be doon for vertu and with pacience. Abstinence, he seith, is little worth, but-if a man have good wille thereto, and but it be enforced by pacience and by charitee, and that men doon it for Goddes sake, and in hope to have the blisse of Hevene.

73. The felawes of Abstinence been Attemperance, that holdeth the mene in alle thinges; eke Shame, that escheweth alle dishoneste; Suffisance, that seeketh no riche metes ne drinkes, ne dooth no force of too outrageous apparelling of mete. Measure also, that restraineth by reason the enslaved appetite of eting; Sobriety also, that restraineth the outrage of drinke; Sparing also, that restraineth the delicate ease to sit long at his mete and softly; wherefore some folk stonden of their owene wille, to eten with the less leisure.

---

## Here followeth Lechery (Middle English)

74. After Glotonye, thanne comth Lecherie; for these two sinnes been so nigh cousins, that ofte tyme they wol not departe. God woot, this sinne is full displeasing thing to God; for He seyde Himself, “Do no lechery.” And therefore He put great peynes against this sinne in the olde lawe. If womman thral were taken in this sinne, she should be beaten with staves to death. And if she were a gentle woman, she should be slain with stones. And if she were a bishop’s daughter, she should have been burnt, by God’s commandment. Further over, by the sinne of Lecherie God dreynt all the world at the deluge. And after that He brent five cities with thunder-lights, and sank them into Hell.

75. Now lat us speke thanne of that stinking sinne of Lecherie that men clepe Avoutrie of wedded folk, that is to seyn if that one of them be wedded, or else both. Saint John seith that avouterers shall be in the lake which burneth with fire and brimstone — in the fire for the lechery, in the brimstone for the stench of their filthiness. Certes, the breking of this sacrament is a horrible thing; it was ordeyned by God Himself in Paradise, and confirmed by Jesu Christ, as witness Saint Matthew in the Gospel: “For this cause shall a man leave father and mother, and shall cleave to his wife, and they twaine shall be one flesh.” This sacrament betokeneth the knitting together of Crist and of Holy Church.

And not only forbade God lechery in deed, but also he commanded that “thou shalt not covet thy neighbour’s wife.” This behest, saith Saint Augustine, comprehendethe forbidding of all desire to do lechery. Behold what Saint Matthew saith in the Gospel: “Whosoever looketh on a woman to lust after her hath committed adultery with her already in his heart.” Here may ye see that not only the doing of this sinne is forbidden, but also the desire to do that sinne. This cursed sinne grievously troubles them whom it haunted. And first, it hurteth the soule; for it constrainteth it to sinne and to the pain of everlastinge deeth. Unto the body it is a tribulation also, for it drawe it, and wasteth and ruineth it, and maketh of his blood a sacrifice to the Fiend of Hell. Also it wasteth richesse and substance. And certes if it be foul thing for a man to waste his good on women, it is yet fouler when women spend on men their goods and their substance for such filthines. This synne, as saith the prophet, robbeth man and woman of good name and of all honour; and it maketh greate joy to the Devil, for by that he wan the more part of the world. And even as a merchant deliteth most in that trafficking where he reapeth the greater profit, so the Fiend deliteth in this filth.

This is the Devyl’s other hand, with five fingers to catch folk into his slavery. The first finger is the foolish interchange of glances between the foolish woman and the foolish man, which killeth as the basilisk killeth by the venom of his sight; for the lust of the eyes followeth the lust of the heart. The second finger is vile touching in wicked manner; whereupon Solomon saith that he who toucheth and handleth a woman fareth like the man that handleth the scorpion which stingeth and suddenly killoth by his poison; even as if any man touche warm pitch, it defileth his fingers. The third is foul words, which are like fire, that soone burn the heart. The fourth finger is kissing; and truly he were a vile fool that would kisse the mouth of a burning oven. The fifth finger is the lustful accord, and then the act is accomplished.

shullen been in helle in a stank brenninge of fyr and of brimston; in fyr, for the lecherie; in brimston, for the stink of hir ordure. Certes, the brekinge of this sacrement is an horrible thing; it was maked of God him-self in paradys, and confermed by Jesu Crist, as witnesseth seint Mathew in the gospel:

> “A man shal lete fader and moder, and taken him to his wyf, and they shullen be two in one of flesh.”

This sacrement bitokneth the knittinge togidre of Crist and of holy chirche. And nat only that God forbad avoutrie in dede, but eek he comanded that thou sholdest nat coveite thy neighbores wyf. In this heeste, seith seint Augustin, is forboden alle manere coveitise to doon lecherie. Lo what seith seint Mathew in the gospel: that “whoso seeth a womman to coveitise of his lust, he hath doon lecherie with hir in his herte.” Here may ye seen that nat only the dede of this sinne is forboden, but eek the desyr to doon that sinne. This cursed sinne anoyeth grevousliche hem that it haunten. And first, to hir soule; for he oblygeth it to sinne and to peyne of deeth that is perdurable. Unto the body anoyeth it grevously eek, for it dreyeth him, and wasteth, and shent him, and of his blood he maketh sacrifyce to the feend of helle; it wasteth his catel and his substaunce. And certes, if it be a foul thing, a man to waste his catel on wommen, yet is it a fouler thing whan that, for swich ordure, wommen dispenden upon men hir catel and substaunce. This sinne, as seith the prophete, bireveth man and womman hir gode fame, and al hir honour; and it is ful pleasaunt to the devel; for therby winneth he the moste partie of this world. And right as a marchant delyteth him most in chaffare that he hath most avantage of, right so delyteth the feend in this ordure.

### §76

This is that other hand of the devel, with five fingres, to cacche the peple to his vileinye. The firste finger is the fool lookinge of the fool womman and of the fool man, that sleeth, right as the basilisk sleeth folk by the venim of his sighte; for the coveitise of eyen folweth the coveitise of the herte. The seconde finger is the vileyns touchinge in wikkede manere; and therfore seith Salomon, that whoso toucheth and handleth a womman, he fareth lyk him that handleth the scorpioun that stingeth and sodainly sleeth through his enveniming; as who-so toucheth warm pich, it shent his fingres. The thridde is foule wordes, that fareth lyk fyr, that right anon brenneth the herte. The fourthe finger is the kisseinge; and trewely he were a greet fool that wolde kisse the mouth of a brenninge ovene or of a fourneys. And more fooles been they that kissen in vileinye; for that mouth is the mouth of helle: and namely, these olde dotardes holours, yet wol they kisse, though they may nat do, and smatre hem. Certes, they been lyk to houndes; for an hound, whan he comth by the roser or by othere busshes, though he may nat pisse, yet wol he heve up his leg and make a countenaunce to pisse. And for that many a man weneth that he may nat sinne, for no likerousnesse that he doth with his wyf; certes, that opinion is fals. God woot, a man may sleen him-self with his owene knyf, and make himselven dronken of his owene tonne. Certes, be it wyf, be it child, or any worldly thing that he loveth bifore God, it is his maumet, and he is an ydolastre. Man sholde loven his wyf by discrecioun, paciently and atemprely; and thanne is she as though it were his suster. The fifthe finger of the develes hand is the stinkinge dede of Lecherie. Certes, the fyve fingres of Glotonie the feend put in the wombe of a man, and with hise fyve fingres of Lecherie he gripeth him by the reynes, for to throwen him into the fourneys of helle; ther-as they shul han the fyr and the wormes that evere shul lasten, and wepinge and wailinge, sharp hunger and thurst, and grimnesse of develes that shullen al to-trede hem, withouten respit and withouten ende. Of Lecherie, as I seyde, sourden diverse speces; as fornicacioun, that is bitwixe man and womman that been nat maried; and this is deedly sinne and agayns nature. Al that is enymee and destruccioun to nature is agayns nature. Parfay, the resoun of a man telleth eek him wel that it is deedly sinne, for-as-muche-as God forbad Lecherie. And seint Paul yeveth hem the regne, that is nat dewe to no wight but to hem that doon deedly sinne.

Another sinne of Lecherie is to bireve a mayden of hir maydenhede; for he that so dooth, certes, he casteth a mayden out of the hyeste degree that is in this present lyf, and bireveth hir thilke precious fruit that the book clepeth *the hundred fruyt*. I ne can seyn it noon other weyes in English, but in Latin it highte *Centesimus fructus*. Certes, he that so dooth is cause of manye damages and vileinyes, mo than any man can rekene; right as he somtyme is cause of alle damages that bestes don in the feeld, that breketh the hegge or the closure; ther-through he destroyeth that which may nat been restored. For certes, na-more may maydenhede be restored than an arm that is smiten fro the body may retourne agayn to wexe. She may have mercy, this woot I wel, if she do penitence; but nevere shal it be that she nas corrupt. And al-be-it so that I have spoken somwhat of Avoutrie, it is good to shewen mo perils that longen to Avoutrie, for to eschue that foule sinne. *Avoutrie*, in Latin, is for to seyn approachinge of other mannes bed, through which tho that whylom weren o flessh abaundone hir bodyes to othere persones. Of this sinne, as seith the wise man, folwen manye harmes. First, brekinge of feith; and certes, in feith is the keye of Cristendom. And whan that feith is broken and lorn, soothly Cristendom stant veyn and withouten fruit. This sinne is eek a thefte; for thefte generally is for to reve a wight his thing agayns his wille. Certes, this is the fouleste thefte that may be, whan a womman steleth hir body from hir housbond and yeveth it to hire holour to defoule hir; and steleth hir soule fro Crist, and yeveth it to the devel. This is a fouler thefte than for to breke a chirche and stele the chalice; for thise avoutiers breken the temple of God spiritually, and stelen the vessel of grace, that is, the body and the soule, for which Crist shal destroyen hem, as seith seint Paul. Soothly of this thefte doutede gretly Joseph, whan that his lordes wyf preyed him of vileinye, whan he seyde, “Lo, my lady, how my lord hath take to me under my warde al that he hath in this world; ne no-thing of his thinges is out of my power, but only ye that been his wyf. And how sholde I thanne do this wickednesse, and sinne so horribly agayns God, and agayns my lord? God it forbede.” Allas! al to litel is swich trouthe now y-founde! The thridde harm is the filthe through which they breken the comaundement of God, and defoulen the auctour of matrimonie, that is Crist. For certes, in-so-muche as the sacrement of mariage is so noble and so digne, so muche is it gretter sinne for to breken it; for God made mariage in paradys, in the estaat of innocence, to multiplye man-kinde to the service of God. And therfore is the brekinge ther-of more grevous. Of which brekinge comen false heires ofte tyme, that wrongfully occupyen folkes heritages. And therfore wol Crist putte hem out of the regne of hevene, that is heritage to gode folk. Of this brekinge comth eek ofte tyme, that folk unware wedden or sinnen with hir owene kinrede; and namely thilke harlottes that haunten bordels of thise fool wommen, that mowe be likned to a commune gonge, whereas men purgen hir ordure. What seye we eek of putours that liven by the horrible sinne of puterie, and constreyne wommen to yelden to hem a certeyn rente of hir bodily puterie, ye, somtyme of his owene wyf or his child; as doon thise baudes? Certes, thise been cursede sinnes. Understond eek, that avoutrie is set gladly in the ten comandements bitwixe thefte and manslaughtre; for it is the gretteste thefte that may be; for it is thefte of body and of soule. And it is lyk to homicide; for it kerveth a-two and breketh a-two hem that first were maked o flesch, and therfore, by the olde lawe of God, they sholde be slayn. But nathelees, by the lawe of Jesu Crist, that is lawe of pitee, whan he seyde to the womman that was founden in avoutrie, and sholde han been slayn with stones, after the wil of the Jewes, as was hir lawe: “Go,” quod Jesu Crist, “and have na-more wil to sinne”; or, “wille na-more to do sinne.” Soothly, the vengeaunce of avoutrie is awarded to the peynes of helle, but if so be that it be destourbed by penitence. Yet been ther mo speces of this cursed sinne; as whan that oon of hem is religious, or elles bothe; or of folk that been entred into ordre, as subdekne or dekne or preest, or hospitaliers. And evere the higher that he is in ordre, the gretter is the sinne. The thinges that gretly agreggen hir sinne is the brekinge of hir avow of chastitee, whan they receyved the ordre. And forther-over, sooth is, that holy ordre is chief of al the tresorie of God, and his especial signe and mark of chastitee; to shewe that they been joyned to chastitee, which that is most precious lyf that is. And thise ordred folk been specially tytled to God, and of the special meynee of God; for which, whan they doon deedly sinne, they been the special traytours of God and of his peple; for they liven of the peple, to preye for the peple, and whyle they been suche traitours, hir preyers availen nat to the peple. Preestes been aungeles, as by the dignitee of hir misterye; but for sothe, seint Paul seith, that “Sathanas transformeth him in an aungel of light.” Soothly, the preest that haunteth deedly sinne, he may be likned to the aungel of derknesse transformed in the aungel of light; he semeth aungel of light, but for sothe he is aungel of derknesse. Swiche preestes been the sones of Helie, as sheweth in the book of Kinges, that they weren the sones of Belial, that is the devel. Belial is to seyn “withouten juge”; and so faren they; hem thinketh they been free, and han no juge, na-more than hath a free bole that taketh which cow that him lyketh in the toun. So faren they by wommen. For right as a free bole is ynough for al a toun, right so is a wikked preest compcioun ynough for al a parisshe, or for al a contree. Thise preestes, as seith the book, ne conne nat the misterie of preesthode to the peple, ne God ne knowe they nat; they ne helde hem nat apayd, as seith the book, of soden flesh that was to hem offred, but they toke by force the flesh that is rawe. Certes, so thise shrewes ne holden hem nat apayd of rosted flesh and sode flesh, with which the peple fedden hem in greet reverence, but they wol have raw flesh of folkes wyves and hir doghtres. And certes, thise wommen that consenten to hir harlotrie doon greet wrong to Crist and to holy chirche and alle halwes, and to alle soules; for they bireven alle thise him that sholde worshipe Crist and holy chirche, and preye for Cristene soules. And therfore han swiche preestes, and hir lemmanes eek that consenten to hir lecherie, the malisoun of al the court Cristen, til they come to amendement. The thridde spece of avoutrie is somtyme bitwixe a man and his wyf; and that is whan they take no reward in hir assembleinge, but only to hire fleshly delyt, as seith seint Jerome; and ne rekken of no-thing but that they been assembled; by cause that they been maried, al is good ynough, as thinketh to hem. But in swich folk hath the devel power, as seyde the aungel Raphael to Thobie; for in hir assembleinge they putten Jesu Crist out of hir herte, and yeven hem-self to alle ordure. The fourthe spece is the assemblee of hem that been of hire kinrede, or of hem that been of oon affinitee, or dees with hem with whiche hir fadres or hir kinrede han deled in the sinne of lecherie; this sinne maketh hem lyk to houndes, that taken no kepe to kinrede. And certes, parentele is in two maneres, outher goostly or fleshly; goostly, as for to delen with hise godsibbes. For right so as he that engendreth a child is his fleshly fader, right so is his godfader his fader espirituel. For which a womman may in no lasse sinne assemblen with hir godsib than with hir owene fleshly brother. The fifthe spece is thilke abhominable sinne, of which that no man unnethe oghte speke ne write; nathelees it is openly reherced in holy writ. This cursednesse doon men and wommen in diverse entente and in diverse manere; but though that holy writ speke of horrible sinne, certes, holy writ may nat been defoulced, na-more than the sonne that shyneth on the mixen. Another sinne aperteneth to lecherie, that comth in slepinge; and this sinne comth ofte to hem that been maydenes, and eek to hem that been corrupt; and this sinne men clepen pollucioun, that comth in foure maneres. Somtyme, of languissinge of body; for the humours been to ranke and habundaunt in the body of man. Somtyme of infermetee; for the feblesse of the vertu retentif, as phisik maketh mencioun. Somtyme, for surfeet of mete and drinke. And somtyme of vileyns thoghtes, that been enclosed in mannes minde whan he goth to slepe; which may nat been withouten sinne. For which men moste kepen hem wysely, or elles may men sinnen ful grevously.

or of a furnace. And the more fools they are who kiss in vileness; for that mouth is the mouth of Hell; and I speak specifically of these old dotard whoremongers, who will yet kiss though they cannot do anything, and so smatter them. Certainly they are like dogs; for a dog, when he passes a rosebush, or other bushes, though he cannot piss, yet will he heave up his leg and make an appearance of pissing. And as for the opinion of many that a man cannot sin for any lechery he does with his wife, certainly that opinion is wrong. God knows, a man may slay himself with his own knife, and make himself drunk out of his own tun. Certainly, be it wife, be it child, or any worldly thing that a man loves bifore God, it is his idol, and he is an idolater. Man should love his wife with discretion, patiently and temperately; and then she is as though she were his sister. The fifth finger of the Devil’s hand is the stinking deed of lechery. Truly, the five fingers of Gluttony the fiend thrusts in the womb of a man, and with his five fingers of Lechery he grips him by the reins, to throw him into the furnaces of Hell; therein shall they have the fire and the everlasting worms, and weeping and wailing, sharp hunger and thirst, and the grimness of devils that shall tread upon them, without respite and without end. Of Lechery, as I said, spring diverse species; as *fornicacioun*, which is betwix man and woman that be not married; and this is deadly sin and against nature. All that is enemy and destruction to nature is against nature. Faith, the reason of a man tells him well that it is deadly sin, since God forbade Lechery. And Saint Paul giveth them the kingdom that is not due to any but to those that do deadly sin.

Another sin of Lechery is to bereave a maiden of her maidenhead; for he that so doeth, certainly he casteth a maiden out of the highest degree that is in this present life, and bereaveth her that precious fruit which the book calleth *the hundred fruit*. I can say it in no other way in English, but in Latin it is called *Centesimus fructus*. Certainly he that so doeth is the cause of many damages and villainies, more than any man can reckon; just as he is sometimes cause of all the damages that beasts do in the field, that break the hedge or the enclosure; through which he destroyeth that which may not be restored. For truly, no more may maidenhead be restored than an arm that is smitten from the body may return again to grow. She may have mercy, this I know well, if she do penance; but never shall it be that she was not corrupt. And albeit I have spoken somewhat of Adultery, it is good to shew more dangers that long to Adultery, in order that men may eschew that foul sin. *Adultery*, in Latin, is to say the approaching of another man’s bed, through which those that were once one flesh abandon their bodies to other persons. Of this sin, as the wise man says, follow many evils. First, breaking of faith; and certainly in faith is the key of Christendom. And when faith is broken and lost, truly Christendom stands vain and without fruit. This sin is also a theft; for theft generally is to deprive a person of his thing against his will. Certainly this is the foulest theft that may be, when a woman steals her body from her husband and gives it to her lecher to defile her; and steals her soul from Christ, and gives it to the devil. This is a fouler theft than to break into a church and steal the chalice; for these adulterers break the temple of God spiritually, and steal the vessel of grace, that is, the body and the soul, for which Christ shall destroy them, as Saint Paul says. Truly of this theft Joseph feared greatly, when his master’s wife entreated him of vileness, when he said, “Lo, my lady, how my lord hath taken to me under my ward all that he hath in this world; nor anything of his things is out of my power, but only ye that are his wife. And how should I then do this wickedness, and sin so horribly against God, and against my lord? God it forbid.” Alas! all too little is such truth now found! The third harm is the filth through which they break the commandment of God and defile the author of matrimony, that is Christ. For certainly, in so much as the sacrament of marriage is so noble and so worthy, so much the more is it a greater sin to break it; for God made marriage in Paradise, in the estate of innocence, to multiply mankind to the service of God. And therefore is the breaking thereof more grievous. Of which breaking often come false heirs, that wrongfully occupy folk’s heritages. And therefore will Christ put them out of the reign of Heaven, that is heritage to good folk. Of this breaking cometh also oftentimes, that folk unwary wed or sin with their own kinred; and namely those harlots that haunt bordels of these foul women, that may be likened to a common cesspool, whereas men purge their ordure. What shall we say also of pimps that live by the horrible sin of procuring, and constrain women to yield to them a certain rent of their bodily prostitution, yes, sometimes of his own wife or his child; as do these bawdes? Certainly these be cursed sins. Understand also that adultery is set gladly in the ten commandments between theft and manslaughter; for it is the greatest theft that may be; for it is theft of body and of soul. And it is like homicide; for it cleaveth asunder and breaketh asunder them that first were made one flesh, and therefore, by the old law of God, they should be slain. But nevertheless, by the law of Jesus Christ, that is law of pity, when he said to the woman that was found in adultery, and should have been slain with stones, after the will of the Jews, as was their law: “Go,” said Jesus Christ, “and have no more will to sin”; or, “will no more to do sin.” Truly the vengeance of adultery is awarded to the pains of Hell, unless it be disturbed by penitence. Yet be there more species of this cursed sin; as when one of them is religious, or else both; or of folk that be entered into order, as sub-deacon or deacon or priest, or hospitaller. And ever the higher that he is in order, the greater is the sin. The things that greatly aggravate their sin is the breaking of their avow of chastity, when they received the order. And furthermore, sooth is, that holy order is chief of all the treasury of God, and his especial sign and mark of chastity; to shew that those who have entered it are joined to chastity, which is the most precious life that is. And these ordered folk be specially titled to God, and of the special meiny of God; for which, when they do deadly sin, they be the special traitors of God and of his people; for they live of the people, to pray for the people, and while they be such traitors, their prayers avail not to the people. Priests be angels, by the dignity of their ministry; but forsooth, Saint Paul saith, that “Satan himself is transformed into an angel of light.” Soothly, the priest that haunteth deadly sin may be likened to an angel of darkness transformed into an angel of light; he seemeth angel of light, but forsooth he is angel of darkness. Such priests be the sons of Eli, as showeth in the Book of Kings, that they were the sons of Belial, that is the devil. Belial is to say “withouten judge”; and so fare they; them thinketh they be free, and have no judge, no more than hath a free bull that taketh which cow that him liketh in the town. So fare they by women. For right as a free bull is enough for all a town, right so is a wicked priest’s corruption enough for all a parish, or for all a country. These priests, as the Book saith, know not the mystery of priesthood to the people, ne God know they not; they holden hem not apaid, as saith the Book, of sodden flesh that was to hem offered, but they toke by force the flesh that is raw. Certes, so these shrewes holden hem not apaid of roasted flesh and sodden flesh, with which the people fed them in great reverence, but they will have raw flesh of folk’s wives and their daughters. And certes, these women that consenten to their harlotrie do great wrong to Christ and to holy church and all halwes, and to all souls; for they bereave all these of him that should worship Christ and holy church, and pray for Christian souls. And therefore have such priests, and their lemmans also that consenten to their lechery, the malison of all the Christian court, till they come to amendement. The third species of adultery is sometimes between a man and his wife; and that is when they take no reward in their assembling, but only for their fleshly delight, as saith Saint Jerome; and reckon of nothing but that they be assembled; because they be married, all is good enough, as thinketh to them. But in such folk hath the devil power, as said the angel Raphael to Tobias; for in their assembling they put Jesus Christ out of their heart, and give themselves to all ordure. The fourth species is the assembling of them that be of their kinred, or of them that be of one affinity, or those with whom their fathers or kinred have dealt in the sin of lechery; this sin maketh them like houndes, that take no keep to kinrede. And certes, parentele is in two maneres, either ghostly or fleshly; ghostly, as for to delen with his godsibbes. For right so as he that engendreth a child is his fleshly father, right so is his godfather his fader espirituel. For which a woman may in no lesser sinne assemble with her godsib than with her own fleshly brother. The fifth species is that abominable sinne, of which no man unnethe ought speak nor write; nevertheless it is openly rehearsed in holy writ. This cursedness do men and women in diverse ententes and in diverse maners; but though holy writ speak of horrible sinne, certes holy writ may not be defouled, no more than the sun that shineth on the muck-heap. Another sinne appertaineth to lechery, that cometh in sleeping; and this sinne cometh ofte to them that be maidens, and eke to them that be corrupt; and this sinne men clepen *pollucioun*, that cometh in four maneres. Somtyme, of languishing of body; for the humours be to ranke and abundant in the body of man. Somtyme, of infirmitee; for the feblesse of the vertu retentif, as physic maketh mention. Somtyme, for surfeit of mete and drinke. And somtyme, of vileyns thoughtes, that be enclosed in mannes mind when he goth to slepe; which may nat be withouten sinne. For which men moste kepe hem wisely, or else may men sinnen full grevously.

## THE PARSON’S TALE

### The Remedy against the Sin of Lechery

Now cometh the remedie against Lecherie, and that is, generally, chastitee and continence, that restraineth alle the desordeyned movinges that comen of fleshly talentes. And evere the greater merite shal he have that most restraineth the wikked eschauffinges of the ordure of this sinne. And this is in two maneres, that is to seyn, chastitee in mariage, and chastitee in widwehode. Now shaltow understonde, that matrimoine is leeful assemblinge of man and of wommen, that receyven by vertu of the sacrament the bond, through which they may nat be departed in al hir lyf, that is to seyn, while that they liven bothe. This, as seith the book, is a ful greet sacrement. God made it, as I have seyd, in paradys, and wolde him-self be born in mariage. And for to holwen mariage, he was at a wedding, whereas he turned water into wyn; which was the first miracle that he wrought on erthe bifore his disciples. The trew effect of mariage is the cleansing of fornication and the replenishing of holy chirche with folk of good lineage; for that is the ende of mariage; and it chaungeth deadly sinne to venial sinne bitwixe them that been wedded, and maketh hem o the hertes, as wel as the bodies. This is trewe mariage, which was established by God er that sinne began, when natural lawe hadde his right estate in Paradys; and it was ordeyned that o man sholde have but o wyf, and o wyf but o man, as seint Augustin seith, and that for many causes.

First, because mariage figuren the union bitwixe Crist and holy chirche. And another is, for that the man is the heed of the womman; at any rate it hath been so ordeigned by ordinance. For if a womman hadde been made... (continues below)

77. Now comth the remedie agayns Lecherie, and that is, generally, Chastitee and Continence, that restreyneth alle the desordeyned moevinges that comen of fleshly talentes. And evere the gretter merite shal he han, that most restreyneth the wikked eschaufiges of the ordure of this sinne. And this is in two maneres, that is to seyn, chastitee in mariage, and chastitee in widwehode. Now shaltow understonde, that matrimoine is leeful assemblinge of man and of womman, that receyven by vertu of the sacrement the bond, through which they may nat be departed in al hir lif, that is to seyn, while that they liven bothe. This, as seith the book, is a ful greet sacrement. God maked it, as I have seyd, in paradys, and wolde him-self be born in mariage. And for to halwen mariage, he was at a weddinge, whereas he turned water into wyn; which was the first miracle that he wrought on erthe bifore his disciples.

Now shaltow understonde that the remediaile of chastitee is in two maneres: in mariage, and in celibacie (widwehode or religion). Matrimony is lawful union of man and woman by which they receive by virtue of the sacrament a bond not to be broken while they both live. This sacrament was ordained by God in Paradise, and He Himself was born in marriage. To sanctify marriage He was at a wedding where He turned water into wine.

First, because marriage figures the union between Christ and holy Church. Another reason is that the man is head of the woman; at any rate, it hath been so ordained. If a woman had... (the treatise proceeds to explain further remedies and precepts, continuing in the text supplied above).

# THE PARSON’S TALE

### 78
First, for marriage is figured between Christ and Holy Church. And that other is, for a man is head of a woman; therefore, by ordinance it should be so. For if a woman had more men than one, then she should have more heads than one, and that were a horrible thing before God; and also a woman could not please many folk at once. And also there should never be peace nor rest among them; for each would demand his own thing. And furthermore, no man should know his own issue, nor who should have his heritage; and the woman should be the less beloved from the time that she were joined to many men.

### 79
Now comes the question how a man should bear himself with his wife; and namely in two things, that is to say, in sufferance and reverence, as Christ showed when He made the first woman. For He made her not of the head of Adam, that she should not claim great lordship. For whereas the woman hath the mastery, she maketh much disorder; there need no examples of this. The experience of day by day ought suffice. Also certainly God made not woman of the foot of Adam, for she should not be held too low; for she can not patiently suffer. But God made woman of the rib of Adam, for woman should be fellow unto man. Man should bear him to his wife in faith, in truth, and in love, as Saint Paul saith: that “a man should love his wife as Christ loved the Church, and gave Himself for it.” So should a man for his wife, if it were need.

### 80
Now how that a woman should be subject to her husband, that telleth Saint Peter. First, in obedience. And eke, as saith the decree, a woman that is a wife, so long as she is a wife, hath no authority to swear nor to bear witness without leave of her husband, that is her lord; in any case, he should be so by reason. She should eke serve him in all honesty, and be temperate of her array. I wot well that they should set their intent to please their husbands, but not by the quaintness of array. Saint Jerome saith that wives that been apparelled in silk and in precious purple may not clothe them in Jesus Christ. What saith Saint John eek in this matter? Saint Gregory eke saith that no wight seeketh precious array but only for vain glory, to be honoured the more before the people. It is a great folly a woman to have fair array outward and be foul inward. A wife should eke be measurable in looking and in bearing and in laughing, and discreet in all her words and her deeds. And above all worldly things she should love her husband with all her heart, and to him be true of her body; so should a husband eke be to his wife. For since that all the body is the husband’s, so should her heart be; or else there is between them two, as in that part, no perfect marriage. Then shall men understand that for three things a man and his wife fleshly may assemble. The first is in intent of engendering children to the service of God, for certes that is the final cause of matrimony. Another cause is, to yield each of them to other the debt of their bodies, for neither of them hath power over his own body. The third is, to eschew lechery and vileness. The fourth is, indeed, deadly sin.

As to the first, it is meritorious; the second also; for, as the law says, she hath merit of chastity who yields to her husband the debt of her body, yea, though it be against her liking and the desire of her heart. The third manner is venial sin, and truly scarce may any of these be without venial sin, for the corruption and for the delight. The fourth manner is, to understand, if they assemble only for amorous love and for none of the foresaid causes, but to accomplish that burning delight, never recking how often, verily it is deadly sin; and yet, with sorrow, some folk will pain themselves more to do it than their appetite sufficeth.

### 81
The second manner of chastity is to be a clean widow, and eschew the embraces of man, and desire the embracing of Jesus Christ. These are those that have been wives and have lost their husbands, and eke women that have done lechery and have been relieved by penitence. And certes, if a wife could keep herself always chaste with leave and licence of her husband, so that she give never occasion that he sin, it were to her a great merit. These manner women that observe chastity must be clean in heart as well as in body and in thought, and measurable in clothing and in countenance; and be abstinent in eating and drinking, in speaking, and in deed. They are the vessel or the box of the blessed Magdalene, that filleth Holy Church of good odour. The third manner of chastity is virginity, and it behoveth that she be holy in heart and clean of body; then is she spouse to Jesus Christ, and she is the life of angels. She is the praise of this world, and she is as these martyrs in equality; she hath in her that which tongue may not tell nor heart think. Virginity bore our Lord Jesus Christ, and virgin was He Himself.

### 82
Another remedy against lechery is specially to withdraw oneself from such things as give occasion to that vileness; as ease, and eating and drinking; for certes, when the pot boileth strongly, the best remedy is to withdraw the fire. Sleeping long in great quiet is eke a great nurse to lechery.

### 83
Another remedy against lechery is that a man or a woman eschew the company of them by whom he doubteth to be tempted; for albeit the deed be withstood, yet is there great temptation. Soothly a white wall, although it burn not fully by the setting of a candle, yet is the wall black of the light. Full oftentimes I rede that no man trust in his own perfection, but he be stronger than Samson, and holier than David, and wiser than Solomon.

### 84
Now after that I have declared you, as I can, the seven deadly sins, and some of their branches and their remedies, soothly, if I could, I would tell you the ten commandments. But so high a doctrine I leave to divines. Natheless, I hope to God they have been touched in this treatise, each of them all.

## Of Confession

### 85
Now forasmuch as the second part of penitence standeth in confession of mouth, as I began in the first chapter, I say Saint Augustine saith: sin is every word and every deed, and all that men covet against the law of Jesus Christ; and this is to sin in heart, in mouth, and in deed, by thy five wits, that be sight, hearing, smelling, tasting or savoring, and feeling. Now it is good to understand that that agregeth much every sin. Thou shalt consider what thou art that doest the sin, whether thou be male or female, young or old, gentle or thrall, free or servant, whole or sick, wedded or single, ordered or unordained, wise or fool, clerk or secular; if she be of thy kindred, bodily or ghostly, or none; if any of thy kindred have sinned with her or none; and many more things.

### 86
Another circumstance is this: whether it be done in fornication, or in adultery, or none; incest, or none; maiden, or none; in manner of homicide, or none; horrible great sins, or small; and how long thou hast continued in sin. The third circumstance is the place where thou hast done sin: whether in other men's house or in thine own; in field or in church, or in churchyard; in a dedicated church, or none. For if the church be hallowed, and man or woman spill his kind in that place by way of sin, or by wicked temptation, the church is interdicted till it be reconciled by the bishop; and the priest that did such a vileness, to the term of all his life, he should never more sing mass; and if he did, he should do deadly sin at every time that he so sang mass. The fourth circumstance is by which mediators or by which messages, as for enticement, or for consenting to bear company with fellowship; for many a wretch, for to bear company, will go to the Devil of Hell. Wherefore they that egg on or consent to the sin be parteners of the sin, and of the damnation of the sinner. The fifth circumstance is how many times he hath sinned, if it be in his mind, and how oft that he hath fallen. For he that oft falleth in sin, he despiseth the mercy of God, and increaseth his sin, and is unkind to Christ; and he waxeth the more feeble to withstand sin, and sinneth the more lightly, and the later riseth, and is the more loath to shrive him, namely to him that is his confessor. For which folk, when they fall again into their old follies, either they forsake their old confessors altogether, or else they depart their shrift in diverse places; but truly such divided shrift deserveth no mercy of God of his sins. The sixth circumstance is why that a man sinneth, as by which temptation; and if himself procure that temptation, or by the exciting of other folk; or if he sin with a woman by force, or by her own assent; or if the woman, maugree her head, hath been enforced or none; this shall she tell; for covetousness, or for poverty, and if it was her procuring, or none; and suchlike matters.

The seventh circumstance is in what manner he hath done his sin, or how that she hath suffered that folk have done to her. And the same shall the man tell plainly, with all circumstances; and whether he hath sinned with common bordel-women, or none; or done his sin in holy times or none; in fasting-times or none; or before confession or after his last shriving; and whether he hath, peradventure, broken therefore his penance enjoined; by whose help and by whose counsel; by sorcery or craft; all must be told. All these things, after that they be great or small, engender the conscience of man. And eke the priest that is thy judge may the better be advised of his judgment in yeving of thy penance, and that is after thy contrition. For understand well that after time that a man hath defiled his baptism by sin, if he will come to salvation, there is no other way but by penitence and shrift and satisfaction; and namely by the two, if there be a confessor to which he may shrive him; and the third, if he have life to perform it.

### 87
Then shall a man look and consider that if he will make a true and a profitable confession, there must be four conditions. First, it must be in sorrowful bitterness of heart, as said King Hezekiah to God: “I will remember all the days of my life in bitterness of heart.” This condition of bitterness hath five signs. The first is that confession must be shamefaced, not to cover nor to hide his sin, for he hath agilt his God and defiled his soul. And thereof saith Saint Augustine: “The heart travaileth for the shame of his sin”; and for he hath great shamefacedness, he is worthy to have great mercy of God. Such was the confession of the publican, who would not heaven up his eyes to heaven, for he had offended God of heaven; for which shamefacedness he had anon the mercy of God. And thereof saith Saint Augustine that such shamefaced folk be next to forgiveness and remission. Another sign is humility in confession; of which saith Saint Peter, “Humble yourselves under the mighty hand of God.” The hand of God is mighty in confession, for thereby God forgiveth thee thy sins; for He alone hath the power. And this humility shall be in heart, and in sign outward; for right as he hath humility to God in his heart, right so should he humble his body outward to the priest that sit in God’s place. For which in no manner, since Christ is sovereign and the priest mean and mediator between Christ and the sinner, and the sinner is the last by way of reason, then should not the sinner sit as high as his confessor, but kneel before him or at his feet, but if malady disturb it. For he shall not take keep who sit there, but in whose place that he sitteth. A man that hath trespassed to a lord, and cometh for to ask mercy and make his accord, and set him down anon by the lord, men would holden him outrageous and not worthy so soon to have remission nor mercy. The third sign is that thy shrift should be full of tears, if man may; and if man may not weep with his bodily eyes, let him weep in his heart. Such was the confession of Saint Peter; for after that he had forsaken Jesus Christ, he went out and wept full bitterly.

### 88
The fourth sign is that he let not for shame to shew his confession. Such was the confession of the Magdalene, that spared not, for no shame of them that were at the feast, to go to our Lord Jesus Christ and bikenow to Him her sins. The fifth sign is that a man or a woman be obedient to receive the penance that to him is enjoined for his sins; for certes Jesus Christ, for the guilt of a man, was obedient unto death.

The second condition of a true confession is that it be hastily done; for certes, if a man had a deadly wound, ever the longer that he tarried to cure himself, the more would it corrupt and hasten him to his death; and eke the wound would be the worse to heal. And right so fareth sin that long time is in a man unshown. Certes, a man ought hastily to shew his sins for many causes; as for dread of death, that cometh oft suddenly, and is in no certain what time it shall be, nor in what place; and eke the fetching of one sin draweth in another; and eke the longer that he tarrieth, the farther he is from Christ. And if he abide to his last day, scarce may he shrive him or remember him of his sins or repent him, for the grievous malady of his death. And forasmuch as he hath not in his life hearkened Jesus Christ when He spake, he shall cry to Jesus Christ at his last day, and scarce will he hearken Him.

# THE PARSON’S TALE

### HERE ENDETH THE SECOND PART OF PENITENCE

Understand that this condition must have four things. Thy shrift must be provided beforehand and considered; for wicked haste brings no profit; and that a man know how to shrive himself of his sins, be they of pride, or of envy, and so forth, according to the species and circumstances; and that he have comprehended in his mind the number and the greatness of his sins, and how long that he hath lain in sin; and also that he be contrite of his sins, and in steadfast purpose, by the grace of God, never again to fall into sin; and also that he dread and watch himself, that he flee the occasions of sin to which he is inclined.

Also thou shalt shrive thee of all thy sins to one man, and not a part to one man and a part to another; that is to understand, when the intention is to divide thy confession out of shame or fear; for this is but the strangling of thy soul. For certes, Jesus Christ is wholly all good; in Him is no imperfection; and therefore either He forgiveth all perfectly or never a deal. I say not that if thou be assigned to the penitent for certain sin, that thou art bound to shew him all the remainder of thy sins, of which thou hast been shriven to thy curate, unless it please thee of thine humility; this is no dividing of shrift.

Nor do I say, where I speak of division of confession, that if thou have licence to shrive thee to a discreet and an honest priest, where thou likest, and by licence of thy curate, that thou mayst not well shrive thee to him of all thy sins. But let no blot be left behind; let no sin be untold, so far as thou hast remembrance of them. And when thou shalt be shriven by thy curate, tell him also all of the sins that thou hast done since last thou wert shriven; and then this will be no wicked intent to divide confession.

Also, true confession asks certain other conditions. First, that thou shrive thee of thy free will, not by constraint, nor for shame, nor for illness, nor for such things; for it is reasonable that he who trespassed of his own free will shall as freely confess it, and that no other man tell his sin, but that he himself do it, nor shall he withhold or deny his sin, nor allow himself to become angry at the priest for admonishing him to leave sin.

Another condition is that thy shrift be lawful; that is to say, that thou who shrivest thee, and also the priest who hears thy confession, be verily of the faith of Holy Church; and that a man be not deprived of hope of the mercy of Jesus Christ, as was Cain or Judas. And also a man must himself accuse himself for his own trespass, and not another; but he shall blame and reproach himself and his own malice for his sin, and not another; nevertheless, if another man be the occasion or enticer of his sin, or the estate of a person be such that because of that person the sin is aggravated, or else that he cannot fully shrive himself without telling of the person with whom he has sinned; then he may tell; so that the intention be not to backbite such a person, but only to declare fully the confession.

Also thou shalt tell no lies in thy confession, as, for humility, perchance, to say that thou hast done sins of which thou wert never guilty. For Saint Augustine says: if thou, by reason of thy humility, liest against thyself, though thou wast not in sin before, yet art thou then in sin because of thy lying. Thou must also confess thy sin with thine own mouth, unless thou grow dumb, and not by letter; for thou hast done the sin and thou shalt have the shame thereof. Also, thou shalt not embellish thy confession with fair and subtle words, the more to cover up the sin; for then thou beguilest thyself and not the priest; thou must tell it plainly, be it ever so foul or so horrible. Thou shalt also shrive thee to a priest that is discreet in counselling thee, and moreover, thou shalt not shrive thee for vainglory, nor hypocritically, nor for any cause other than the fear of Jesus Christ and the health of thy soul. Also, thou shalt not run suddenly to the priest to tell him lightly of thy sin, as one would tell a jest or a tale, but advisedly and with great devotion. And generally speaking, shrive thee often. If thou fall often, then thou risest by confession. And though thou shrive thee more than once of sin for which thou hast been already shriven, it is the more merit. And, as Saint Augustine says, thou shalt thereby the more easily obtain release from and the grace of God, both as to sin and punishment. And certainly, once a year, at the least, it is lawful to receive the Eucharist; for truly, once a year all things are renewed.

This prayer must be truly said and in very faith, and that men pray to God orderly and discreetly and devoutly; and always a man shall put his will to be subject to the will of God. This prayer must also be said with great humility and all innocently; honorably, and not to the annoyance of any man or woman. It must also be followed by works of charity. It availeth also against the vices of the soul; for, as Saint Jerome says, “By fasting we are saved from the vices of the flesh, and by prayer from the vices of the soul.”

After this, thou shalt understand that bodily pain stands in waking; for Jesus Christ says, “Watch ye, and pray, that ye enter not into temptation.” Ye shall understand also, that fasting stands in three things: in forbearing of bodily meat and drink, and in forbearing of worldly jollity, and in forbearing of deadly sin; this is to say, that a man shall keep him from deadly sin with all his might.

And thou shalt understand also that God ordained fasting; and to fasting appertain four things: largeness to poor folk, gladness of spiritual heart (not to be angry nor annoyed, nor to grudge because one fasts), and also reasonable hours for eating by measure; that is to say, a man shall not eat out of season, nor sit the longer at his table to eat because he has fasted.

Then shalt thou understand that bodily pain stands in discipline or teaching, by word or by writing, or in example. Also in wearing of hair shirts or of coarse straw, or of hauberjons on the naked flesh, for Christ’s sake, and such manner of penances. But beware well that such manner of penances on thy flesh make not thy heart bitter or angry or annoyed with thyself; for better is to cast away thine hair than to cast away the meekness of Jesus Christ. And therefore Saint Paul says: “Clothe you, as they that be chosen of God, in heart of mercy, debonairtee, sufferance, and such manner of clothing”; of which Jesus Christ is more pleased than of hair-shirts, or hauberjons, or hauberks.

Then is discipline also in smiting of thy breast, in scourging with rods, in kneelings, in tribulations; in suffering patiently wrongs that be done to thee, and also in patient sufferance of maladies, or loss of worldly chattels, or of wife, or of child, or other friends.

Then shalt thou understand which things disturb penance; and this is in four manners, that is, dread (fear), shame, hope, and despair. And to speak first of dread: for which he thinketh that he may suffer no penance; thereto is remedy to think that bodily penance is but short and little in regard of the pain of Hell, that is so cruel and so long that it lasteth without end.

Now against the shame that a man hath to shrive him, and namely these hypocrites that would be held so perfect that they have no need to shrive them — against that shame should a man think that, by way of reason, he that hath not been ashamed to do foul things, certes he ought not to be ashamed to do fair (good) things, and of such is confession. A man should also think that God seeth and knoweth all his thoughts and all his works; to Him may nothing be hid nor covered. Men should also remember the shame that is to come at the day of doom to them that be not penitent and shriven in this present life. For all the creatures in earth and in hell shall openly see all that they hid in this world.

Now, for to speak of the hope of them that be negligent and slow to shrive them, that standeth in two manners. That one is, that he hopeth to live long and to purchase much wealth for his delight, and then he will shrive him; and, as he saith, it seemeth to him then timely enough to come to shrift. Another is, presumption that he hath in Christ’s mercy. Against the first vice, he shall think that our life is in no surety; and also that all the riches of this world be in aventure, and pass as a shadow on the wall. And, as Saint Gregory saith, it appertaineth to the great righteousness of God that never shall the pain stint of them that never would withdraw them from sin, their thanks, but aye continue in sin; for that perpetual will to do sin shall they have perpetual pain.

Despair is in two manners: the first despair is concerning the mercy of Christ; the other is that they think that they might not long persevere in goodness. The first despair cometh of that he deemeth that he hath sinned so greatly and so often, and so long lain in sin, that he shall not be saved. Certes, against that cursed despair he should think that the Passion of Jesus Christ is more strong to unbind than sin is strong to bind. Against the second despair, he shall think that as often as he falleth he may arise again by penitence. And though he never so long have lain in sin, the mercy of Christ is always ready to receive him to mercy. Against the despair that he deemeth that he shall not long persevere in goodness, he shall think that the weakness of the devil may nothing do except men will suffer him; and also he shall have strength by the help of God, and of all Holy Church, and of the protection of angels, if him list.

Then shall men understand what is the fruit of penance; and, after the word of Jesus Christ, it is the endless bliss of Heaven, there joy hath no contrary of woe nor grievance; there all harms be passed of this present life; there is surety from the pain of Hell; there is the blissful company that rejoice them evermore, each of other’s joy; there the body of man, that whilom was foul and dark, is more dear than the sun; there the body, that whilom was sick, frail, and feeble, and mortal, is immortal, and so strong and so whole that there may nothing impair it; there is neither hunger, thirst, nor cold, but every soul replenished with the sight of the perfect knowing of God. This blissful reign may men purchase...

---

### HERE FOLLOWETH THE THIRD PART OF SATISFACTION

#### 91.

Now have I told you of veray Confession, that is the second part of Penitence.

The third part of Penitence is Satisfaction; and that standeth most generally in alms and in bodily pain. Now there be three manners of alms: contrition of heart, where a man offereth himself to God; another is to have pity of default of his neighbours; and the third is in giving of good counsel, ghostly and bodily, where men have need, and namely in sustenance of men’s food. And take keep, that a man hath need of these things generally: he hath need of food, he hath need of clothing and harbour, he hath need of charitable counsel, and visiting in prison and in sickness, and sepulture of his dead body. And if thou mayst not visit the needful with thy person, visit him by thy message and by thy gifts. These be generally alms or works of charity of them that have temporal riches or discretion in counseling. Of these works shalt thou hear at the day of doom.

#### 92.

These alms shalt thou do of thine own proper things, and hastily, and privily if thou mayst; but nevertheless, if thou mayst not do it privily, thou shalt not forbear to do alms though men see it; so that it be not done for the thanks of the world, but only for the thanks of Jesus Christ. For as witnesseth Saint Matthew, capitulo quinto: 

> “A city that is set on a hill cannot be hid; neither do men light a candle and put it under a bushel, but set it on a candlestick, to give light to them that be in the house. Right so shall your light lighten before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in Heaven.”

#### 93.

Now as to speak of bodily pain, it standeth in prayers, in wakings, in fastings, in virtuous teaching of orisons. And ye shall understand that orisons or prayers be to say a pitiful will of heart that redresseth it in God and expresseth it by word outward, to remove harms and to have things spiritual and durable, and sometime temporal things; of which orisons, certes, in the orison of the *Pater-noster*, hath Jesus Christ enclosed most things. Certes, it is privileged of three things in his dignity, for which it is more dignified than any other prayer: for that Jesus Christ himself made it; and it is short, so that it should be learned the more lightly, and to be withheld the more easily in heart, and to help himself the oftener with the orison; and that a man should be the less weary to say it, and that a man may not excuse himself to learn it, it is so short and so easy; and for it comprehendeth in itself all good prayers. The exposition of this holy prayer, that is so excellent and dignified, I bytake to these masters of theology; save thus much will I say: that, when thou prayest that God should forgive thee thy trespasses as thou forgivest them that trespass to thee, be full well ware that thou be not out of charitee. This holy orison diminish[eth] eke venial sin; and therefore it appertaineth specially to penitence.

#### 94.

This prayer must be truly said and in very faith, and that men pray to God orderly and discreetly and devoutly; and always a man shall put his will to be subject to the will of God. This orison must also be said with great humbleness and full pure; honestly, and not to the annoyance of any man or woman. It must also be continued with the works of charity. It availeth also against the vices of the soul; for, as Saint Jerome saith, “By fasting are the vices of the flesh saved, and by prayer the vices of the soul.”

#### 95.

After this, thou shalt understand that bodily pain standeth in waking; for Jesu Crist saith, “Wake ye, and pray that ye ne enter into wicked temptation.” Ye shall understand also, that fasting standeth in three things: in forbearing of bodily meat and drink, and in forbearing of worldly jollity, and in forbearing of deadly sin; this is to say, that a man shall keep him from deadly sin with all his might.

#### 96.

And thou shalt understand also that God ordained fasting; and to fasting appertain four things. Largeness to poor folk, gladness of the heart spiritual, not to be angry nor annoyed, nor grudge for he fasteth; and also reasonable hour for to eat by measure; that is to say, a man shall not eat out of time, nor sit the longer at his table to eat because he fasteth.

#### 97.

Then shalt thou understand that bodily pain standeth in discipline or teaching, by word or by writing, or in example. Also in wearing of hair-shirts or of straw, or of haubergeons on the naked flesh, for Christ’s sake, and such manner penances. But beware thee well that such manner penances on thy flesh do not make thine heart bitter or angry or annoyed of thyself; for better is to cast away thine hair than to cast away the meekness of Jesu Crist. And therefore saith Saint Paul: “Clothe you, as they that be chosen of God, in heart of mercy, debonairtee, sufferance, and such manner of clothing”; of which Jesu Crist is more pleased than of hair-shirts, or haubergeons, or hauberks.

#### 98.

Then is discipline also in knocking of thy breast, in scourging with rods, in kneelings, in tribulations; in suffering patiently wrongs that be done to thee, and also in patient sufferance of maladies, or the losing of worldly chattel, or of wife, or of child, or other friends.

#### 99.

Then shalt thou understand which things disturb penance; and this is in four manners, that is, dread, shame, hope, and despair. And to speak first of dread: for which he thinketh that he may suffer no penance; thereagainst is remedy to think that bodily penance is but short and little in regard of the pain of Hell, that is so cruel and so long, that it lasteth without end.

#### 100.

Now against the shame that a man hath to shrive him, and namely these hypocrites that would be held so perfect that they have no need to shrive them; against that shame should a man think that, by way of reason, he that hath not been ashamed to do foul things, certes he ought not to be ashamed to do fair (good) things, and of such is confession. A man should also think that God seeth and knoweth all his thoughts and all his works; to Him may no thing be hid nor covered. Men should also remember the shame that is to come at the day of doom to them that be not penitent and shriven in this present life; for all the creatures in earth and in hell shall see openly all that they hid in this world.

#### 101.

Now for to speak of the hope of them that be negligent and slow to shrive them, that standeth in two manners. That one is, that he hopeth to live long and to purchase much riches for his delight, and then he will shrive him; and, as he saith, it seemeth to him then timely enough to come to shrift. Another is surquidry (presumption) that he hath in Christ’s mercy. Against the first vice, he shall think that our life is in no surety; and also that all the riches in this world be in adventure, and pass as a shadow on the wall. And, as saith Saint Gregory, that it appertaineth to the great righteousness of God, that never shall the pain stint of them that never would withdraw them from sin their thanks, but aye continue in sin; for that perpetual will to do sin shall they have perpetual pain.

#### 102.

Despair (wanhope) is in two manners: the first despair is concerning the mercy of Christ; the other is that they think that they might not long persevere in goodness. The first despair cometh of that he deemeth that he hath sinned so greatly and so often, and so long lain in sin, that he shall not be saved. Certes, against that cursed despair he should think that the Passion of Jesu Christ is more strong to unbind than sin is strong to bind. Against the second despair, he shall think that as oft as he falleth he may arise again by penitence. And though he never so long have lain in sin, the mercy of Christ is always ready to receive him to mercy. Against the despair that he deemeth that he should not long persevere in goodness, he shall think that the feebleness of the devil may nothing do unless men will suffer him; and also he shall have strength of the help of God, and of all Holy Church, and of the protection of angels, if him list.

#### 103.

Then shall men understand what is the fruit of penance; and, after the word of Jesu Christ, it is the endless bliss of Heaven, where joy hath no contrariety of woe nor grievance; where all harms be passed of this present life; where is the surety from the pain of Hell; where is the blissful company that rejoice them evermore, each of other’s joy; where the body of man, that whilom was foul and dark, is more dear than the sun; where the body, that whilom was sick, frail, and feeble, and mortal, is immortal, and so strong and so whole that there may nothing impair it; where there is neither hunger, thirst, nor cold, but every soul replenished with the sight of the perfect knowing of God. This blissful reign may men purchase by true penitence and satisfaction and by the grace of God.

HERE ENDETH THE THIRD PART OF SATISFACTION

THE CANTERBURY TALES

# THE PARSON’S TALE

Hell shall openly behold all that sinners hide in this world.

Now to speak of the hope of those who are negligent and slow in shriving themselves—that is of two sorts. The one is, that he hopes to live long and to acquire riches for his delight, and then he will shrive himself; and as he tells himself, it seems to him that it will then be time enough to go to confession. Another is the over-confidence that he has in Christ’s mercy. Against the first vice he shall think, that our life is in no security; and also that all the riches in this world are at hazard, and pass as does a shadow on the wall. And, as Saint Gregory says, it is part of the great righteousness of God that never shall the torment cease of those that would never withdraw themselves willingly from sin, but have always continued in sin; because, for the perpetual will to sin, they shall have perpetual torment.

Despair is of two sorts: the first is of the mercy of Christ; the other is the thought of sinners that they cannot long persevere in goodness. The first despair comes of the thought that he has sinned so greatly and so often, and has lain so long in sin, that he shall not be saved. Certainly, against that accursed despair should be set the thought that the passion of Jesus Christ is stronger to loose than sin is strong to bind. Against the second despair, let him think that as often as he falls he may rise again by penitence. And though he may have lain in sin ever so long, the mercy of Christ is ever ready to receive him into grace. Against that form of despair wherein he deems that he should not long persevere in goodness, he shall think that the feebleness of the Devil can do nothing unless men allow him to; and also that he shall have the strength of the help of God and of all Holy Church and of the protection of angels, if he will.

Then shall men understand what is the fruit of penance; and according to the word of Jesus Christ, it is the endless bliss of Heaven, where joy has no opposite of woe or grievance, where all evils of this present life are past; wherein is security from the torments of Hell; wherein is the blessed company that rejoices evermore, each of the others’ joy; wherein the body of man, that formerly was foul and dark, is more bright than the sun; wherein the body, that lately was ailing, frail, and feeble, and mortal, is immortal, and so strong and so whole that nothing may impair it; wherein is no hunger nor thirst, nor cold, but every soul is replenished with the ability to perceive the perfect knowing of God. This blessed kingdom may man acquire by poverty of spirit, and the glory of humbleness, and the plenitude of joy by hunger and thirst, and the ease and rest by labour, and life by death and the mortification of sin.

> By poverty of spirit, and the glory by lowliness;  
> the plentitude of joy by hunger and thirst, and the  
> rest by travail; and the life by death and mortification of sin.

## Envoi

Now do I pray all those who hear this little treatise, or read it, that, if there be within it anything that pleases them, they thank Our Lord Jesus Christ, from Whom proceeds all understanding and all goodness. And if there be anything that displeases them, I pray them, also, that they impute it to the fault of my ignorance and not to my intention, which would fain have better said if I had had the knowledge. For our Book says, “All that is written is written for our instruction”; and that was my intention. Wherefore I meekly beseech you that, for the sake of God’s mercy, you pray for me that Christ have mercy upon me and forgive me my trespasses — and especially for my translations and the writing of worldly vanities, which I withdraw in my retractations: as, *The Book of Troilus*; also *The Book of Fame*; *The Book of the Nineteen Ladies*; *The Book of the Duchess*; *The Book of Saint Valentine’s Day*, *Of the Parliament of Birds*; *The Tales of Canterbury*, those that tend toward sin; *The Book of the Lion*; and many another book, were they in my remembrance; and many a song and many a lecherous lay,— to which may Christ, of His great mercy, forgive me the sin. But for the translation of Boethius’s *De Consolatione*, and other books of legends of saints, and homilies, and of morality and devotion — for those I thank Our Lord Jesus Christ and His Blessed Mother and all the saints of Heaven; beseeching them that they, henceforth unto my life’s end, send me grace whereof to bewail my sins, and to study for the salvation of my soul: — and grant me the grace of true penitence, confession, and expiation in this present life; through the benign grace of Him Who is King of kings and Priest over all priests, Who redeemed us with the precious blood of His heart; so that I may be one of those, at the day of doom, that shall be saved: *Qui cum Patre, etc.*

## Middle English (Original)

Now preye I to hem alle that herkne this litel tretis or rede, that if ther be any thing in it that liketh hem, that therof they thanken oure Lord Jesu Crist, of whom procedeth al wit and al goodnesse. And if ther be any thing that displese hem, I preye hem also that they arrette it to the defaute of myn unconninge, and nat to my wil, that wolde ful fayn have seyd bettre if I hadde had conninge. For oure boke seith, “Al that is writen is writen for oure doctrine”; and that is myn entente. Wherfore I biseke yow mekely for the mercy of God, that ye preye for me, that Crist have mercy on me and foryeve me my giltes: — and namely, of my translacions and endytinges of worldly vanitees, the whiche I revoke in my retracciouns: as is the book of Troilus; the book also of Fame; the book of the Nynetene Ladies; the book of the Duchesse; the book of Seint Valentynes day of the Parlement of Briddes; the tales of Caunterbury, thilke that sounen into sinne; the book of the Leoun; and many another book, if they were in my remembrance; and many a song and many a lecherous lay; that Crist for his grete mercy foryeve me the sinne.

But of the translacion of Boece de Consolacione, and othere bokes of Legendes of seintes, and omelies, and moralitee, and devocioun, that thanke I oure Lord Jesu Crist and his blisful moder, and alle the seintes of hevene; bisekinge hem that they from hennesforth unto my lyves ende sende me grace to biwayle my giltes, and to studie to the salvacioun of my soule: — and graunte me grace of verray penitence, confessioun and satisfaccioun to doon in this present lyf; thurgh the benigne grace of him that is king of kinges and preest over alle preestes, that boghte us with the precious blood of his herte; so that I may been oon of hem at the day of dome that shulle be saved: *Qui cum Patre, &c.*
